name: Childhood Absence Epilepsy (CAE) - Typical Absence

morphology.interictal: Normal background, occasional 3 Hz spike-and-wave
morphology.ictal: Generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave, abrupt onset/offset, synchronous

hyperventilation.notes: Most effective activation procedure for CAE. Provokes absence seizures in most patients.

photic_stimulation.notes: Less effective than hyperventilation for CAE

sleep.notes: May show different morphology during sleep (faster frequency)

recording_duration.notes: Longer recordings increase yield

manifestation: May have eye fluttering or automatisms
clinical_features.development: Usually normal, may have mild learning difficulties

clinical_course.progression: May persist into adolescence, often remits
clinical_course.outcome: Good prognosis, 60-70% remit by adolescence
clinical_course.treatment: Ethosuximide, valproate, lamotrigine
clinical_course.prognosis: Excellent if treated early

abret_pearls: Hyperventilation is the most effective activation procedure for CAE (90-95% yield).
3 Hz spike-and-wave is generalized, symmetric, and synchronous - distinguishing it from focal discharges.
Background is usually normal in CAE, distinguishing it from symptomatic generalized epilepsies.
differential_diagnosis: Juvenile Absence Epilepsy (JAE) - older age, faster frequency
Absence with Eyelid Myoclonus (Jeavons) - has eyelid myoclonus, photosensitive
Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME) - includes myoclonus
Atypical Absence (LGS) - gradual onset/offset, slower frequency, cognitive impairment
Focal epilepsy with secondary generalization - asymmetric onset

name: Juvenile Absence Epilepsy (JAE) - Typical Absence

morphology.interictal: Normal background, occasional 3-4 Hz spike-and-wave
morphology.ictal: Generalized 3-4 Hz spike-and-wave, may be faster than CAE

hyperventilation.notes: Less effective than in CAE but still useful

sleep.notes: May show different morphology during sleep

recording_duration.notes: Longer recordings increase yield

manifestation: Less frequent than CAE (fewer per day)

clinical_course.outcome: Good prognosis, may remit or persist
clinical_course.treatment: Valproate, lamotrigine, ethosuximide
clinical_course.prognosis: Good, but may be less likely to remit than CAE

abret_pearls: JAE has faster spike-and-wave frequency (3-4 Hz) compared to CAE (3 Hz).
JAE patients are older (adolescents) compared to CAE (children).
JAE may have associated generalized tonic-clonic seizures, unlike pure CAE.
differential_diagnosis: Childhood Absence Epilepsy (CAE) - younger age, slower frequency
Absence with Eyelid Myoclonus (Jeavons) - has eyelid myoclonus, photosensitive
Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME) - includes myoclonus
Atypical Absence (LGS) - gradual onset/offset, slower frequency, cognitive impairment
Focal epilepsy with secondary generalization

name: Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME)

morphology.interictal: Normal background, polyspike-and-wave, 4-6 Hz spike-and-wave
morphology.ictal: Polyspike-and-wave or 4-6 Hz spike-and-wave
morphology.special_features: Polyspike-and-wave (multiple spikes followed by slow wave) is more common in JME than pure 3 Hz spike-and-wave. Myoclonus often occurs upon awakening.

sleep_deprivation.protocol: 4-6 hours sleep deprivation, record upon awakening
sleep_deprivation.notes: Most effective for JME. Myoclonus often occurs upon awakening.

photic_stimulation.notes: May provoke myoclonic jerks in photosensitive patients

hyperventilation.notes: Less effective than sleep deprivation for JME

sleep.notes: Myoclonus often occurs upon awakening from sleep

recording_duration.recommended: Include sleep and awakening, minimum 30 minutes
recording_duration.notes: Record upon awakening - critical for JME

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Record upon awakening - myoclonus is most common at this time

clinical_course.outcome: Good response to treatment but requires lifelong medication
clinical_course.treatment: Valproate (first line), lamotrigine, levetiracetam, topiramate
clinical_course.prognosis: Good with treatment, but medication non-compliance leads to recurrence

abret_pearls: Sleep deprivation with recording upon awakening is the most effective activation procedure for JME (90-95% yield).
Myoclonus upon awakening is the most characteristic feature of JME.
Polyspike-and-wave is more common in JME than pure 3 Hz spike-and-wave.
differential_diagnosis: Childhood Absence Epilepsy (CAE) - no myoclonus, younger age
Juvenile Absence Epilepsy (JAE) - no myoclonus
Progressive myoclonus epilepsies - progressive course, abnormal exam

name: West Syndrome (Infantile Spasms)

morphology.interictal: Hypsarrhythmia - chaotic high-amplitude slow waves with multifocal spikes
morphology.ictal: Electrodecremental pattern - generalized attenuation

sleep.notes: Hypsarrhythmia is most prominent during sleep. Essential to record sleep.

awake.notes: Hypsarrhythmia present but may be less prominent

ictal_recording.notes: Electrodecremental pattern during spasms. Must correlate with clinical events.

recording_duration.notes: Sleep is essential - hypsarrhythmia is most prominent during sleep

video_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG changes with clinical spasms

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Sleep recording is CRITICAL - hypsarrhythmia is most prominent during sleep

clinical_features.development: Developmental delay or regression is common

clinical_course.progression: May evolve to other seizure types
clinical_course.outcome: Variable - depends on underlying cause
clinical_course.treatment: ACTH, vigabatrin, prednisolone, ketogenic diet
clinical_course.prognosis: Variable - poor if symptomatic, better if cryptogenic. Early treatment improves outcome.

abret_pearls: Hypsarrhythmia is most prominent during sleep - sleep recording is CRITICAL for diagnosis.
Electrodecremental pattern during spasms - generalized attenuation correlates with clinical events.
West Syndrome = Infantile Spasms + Hypsarrhythmia + Developmental Delay/Regression (triad).
differential_diagnosis: Benign myoclonus of infancy - normal EEG
Other infantile epilepsies - different EEG patterns
Non-epileptic events - normal EEG

name: Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome (LGS)

morphology.interictal: Slow spike-and-wave (1.5-2.5 Hz), generalized paroxysmal fast activity (GPFA)
morphology.ictal: Slow spike-and-wave, tonic seizures show GPFA or electrodecremental pattern

sleep.notes: Slow spike-and-wave and GPFA are most prominent during sleep. Essential to record sleep.

awake.notes: Slow spike-and-wave present but may be less frequent

ictal_recording.notes: GPFA or electrodecremental pattern during tonic seizures. Must correlate with clinical events.

recording_duration.notes: Sleep is essential - patterns are most prominent during sleep

video_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG changes with multiple seizure types

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Sleep recording is CRITICAL - slow spike-and-wave and GPFA are most prominent during sleep

manifestation: Tonic seizures (most characteristic) - brief, often during sleep
Atypical absence - gradual onset/offset, longer than typical absence
Atonic seizures - drop attacks (sudden loss of tone, falls)
Status epilepticus - may occur (non-convulsive or convulsive)

clinical_course.outcome: Poor - resistant to treatment, persistent seizures
clinical_course.treatment: Valproate, lamotrigine, rufinamide, felbamate, ketogenic diet, VNS
clinical_course.prognosis: Poor - persistent seizures, cognitive impairment, poor quality of life

abret_pearls: Slow spike-and-wave (1.5-2.5 Hz) is characteristic of LGS - slower than typical 3 Hz spike-and-wave.
GPFA (generalized paroxysmal fast activity) during sleep is highly characteristic of LGS.
Multiple seizure types + slow spike-and-wave + cognitive impairment = LGS triad.
Drop attacks (atonic seizures) are common in LGS - sudden loss of tone causing falls.
Status epilepticus may occur in LGS - both non-convulsive (atypical absence status) and convulsive forms.
differential_diagnosis: Childhood Absence Epilepsy (CAE) - 3 Hz spike-and-wave, normal cognition
Doose Syndrome (MAE) - myoclonic-astatic, different EEG
Other developmental epileptic encephalopathies

name: Benign Rolandic Epilepsy (BRE) / Benign Epilepsy with Centrotemporal Spikes (BECTS)

morphology.interictal: Centrotemporal spikes (C3, C4, T3, T4) - high amplitude, diphasic
morphology.ictal: Focal onset in centrotemporal region, may spread
morphology.distribution: Focal - centrotemporal (C3, C4, T3, T4), may be bilateral independent

sleep.notes: Centrotemporal spikes are dramatically activated by sleep. Essential to record sleep.

awake.notes: Spikes may be present but less frequent

recording_duration.notes: Sleep is essential - spikes are dramatically activated by sleep

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Sleep recording is CRITICAL - centrotemporal spikes are dramatically activated by sleep (10-100x increase)

clinical_features.seizure_type: Focal seizures with or without impaired awareness

clinical_course.outcome: Excellent - remits by age 13-16 years
clinical_course.treatment: May not require treatment if infrequent. If treated: carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, levetiracetam
clinical_course.prognosis: Excellent - complete remission by adolescence, normal development

abret_pearls: Centrotemporal spikes are dramatically activated by sleep (10-100x increase) - sleep recording is CRITICAL.
High-amplitude, diphasic spikes in centrotemporal region (C3, C4, T3, T4) are characteristic.
BRE is benign - remits by adolescence with normal development, distinguishing it from symptomatic focal epilepsies.
differential_diagnosis: Symptomatic focal epilepsy - abnormal exam/imaging, persistent
Other benign focal epilepsies - different locations
Panayiotopoulos syndrome - occipital spikes

name: Temporal Lobe Epilepsy (TLE)

morphology.interictal: Temporal spikes/sharp waves, temporal slowing
morphology.ictal: Focal onset in temporal region, rhythmic theta/delta evolving to faster frequencies
morphology.distribution: Focal - temporal (T3, T4, T5, T6, F7, F8), may be mesial or lateral

sleep.notes: Temporal spikes are activated by sleep. Important to record sleep.

awake.notes: Spikes may be present but less frequent

ictal_recording.notes: Ictal onset pattern is critical for localization. Must correlate with clinical semiology.

recording_duration.notes: Longer recordings increase yield, sleep is important

montage.recommended: Bipolar montage (longitudinal and transverse), referential for field analysis
montage.notes: Better localizes temporal spikes and ictal onset

video_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG changes with clinical semiology

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Sleep recording increases yield. Ictal recording is critical for surgical planning.

clinical_features.seizure_type: Focal seizures with or without impaired awareness
clinical_features.imaging: May show hippocampal sclerosis, mesial temporal sclerosis, or other lesions

clinical_course.progression: Chronic, may be progressive if structural lesion
clinical_course.outcome: Variable - may be controlled with medication or require surgery
clinical_course.treatment: Carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, levetiracetam, lamotrigine. Surgery if medication-resistant.
clinical_course.prognosis: Variable - good if medication-responsive, excellent if surgery-responsive

abret_pearls: Temporal spikes are activated by sleep - sleep recording increases yield.
Ictal onset pattern (rhythmic theta/delta evolving to faster frequencies) is critical for localization.
Mesial temporal sclerosis is the most common cause of TLE - look for hippocampal atrophy on MRI.
differential_diagnosis: Frontal lobe epilepsy - different semiology, different ictal pattern
Parietal lobe epilepsy - different semiology
Occipital lobe epilepsy - different semiology

name: Frontal Lobe Epilepsy (FLE)

morphology.interictal: Frontal spikes/sharp waves, frontal slowing
morphology.ictal: Focal onset in frontal region, rapid evolution, may be brief
morphology.frequency: Variable - may be very fast (beta/gamma) or slower
morphology.distribution: Focal - frontal (F3, F4, Fz, F7, F8), may be mesial or lateral

sleep.notes: Frontal spikes are activated by sleep. Important to record sleep.

awake.notes: Spikes may be present but less frequent

ictal_recording.notes: Ictal onset pattern is critical for localization. Seizures may be brief and frequent.

recording_duration.notes: Longer recordings increase yield, sleep is important

montage.recommended: Bipolar montage (longitudinal and transverse), referential for field analysis
montage.notes: Better localizes frontal spikes and ictal onset. May need additional frontal electrodes.

video_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG changes with clinical semiology. Seizures may be brief.

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Sleep recording increases yield. Ictal recording is critical - seizures may be brief and frequent.

clinical_features.seizure_type: Focal seizures with or without impaired awareness
clinical_features.imaging: May show structural lesions (tumors, cortical dysplasia, etc.)

clinical_course.outcome: Variable - may be controlled with medication or require surgery
clinical_course.treatment: Carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, levetiracetam, lamotrigine. Surgery if medication-resistant.
clinical_course.prognosis: Variable - good if medication-responsive, excellent if surgery-responsive

abret_pearls: Frontal spikes are activated by sleep - sleep recording increases yield.
Frontal seizures are often brief and frequent - longer recordings may be needed.
Ictal onset pattern is critical for localization - may be very fast (beta/gamma) or slower.
differential_diagnosis: Temporal lobe epilepsy - different semiology, different ictal pattern
Non-epileptic events - normal EEG
Other focal epilepsies - different locations

name: Absence with Eyelid Myoclonus (Jeavons Syndrome)

morphology.interictal: Normal background, occasional 3-4 Hz spike-and-wave or polyspike-and-wave
morphology.ictal: Generalized 3-4 Hz spike-and-wave or polyspike-and-wave, often triggered by eye closure or photic stimulation
morphology.frequency: 3-4 Hz (may be faster than typical absence)
morphology.duration: Brief (3-6 seconds, shorter than typical absence)
morphology.special_features: Eyelid myoclonus (rhythmic jerking of eyelids), often triggered by eye closure or photic stimulation

photic_stimulation.notes: MOST EFFECTIVE for Jeavons. Highly photosensitive. Eye closure during IPS may trigger events.

eye_closure.notes: Eye closure often triggers eyelid myoclonus and absence. Critical activation procedure.

hyperventilation.notes: Less effective than photic stimulation for Jeavons

sleep.notes: Less effective than photic stimulation

recording_duration.recommended: Minimum 20-30 minutes awake, include photic stimulation and eye closure
recording_duration.notes: Must include photic stimulation and eye closure testing

montage.notes: Better shows generalized distribution. May need EOG channels to see eyelid myoclonus.

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Photic stimulation and eye closure are CRITICAL - Jeavons is highly photosensitive and eye closure triggers events

manifestation: Eyelid myoclonus (rhythmic jerking of eyelids) - MOST CHARACTERISTIC
Brief absence seizures (3-6 seconds, shorter than typical absence)
Often triggered by photic stimulation (highly photosensitive)
Upward deviation of eyes during eyelid myoclonus
May have brief myoclonic jerks of upper extremities

clinical_course.progression: May persist into adulthood, often lifelong
clinical_course.outcome: Variable - may remit or persist
clinical_course.treatment: Valproate (first line), lamotrigine, levetiracetam, ethosuximide. Avoid photosensitivity triggers.
clinical_course.prognosis: Good with treatment, but photosensitivity may persist. Avoidance of triggers is important.

abret_pearls: Photic stimulation is the most effective activation procedure for Jeavons (90-95% yield) - highly photosensitive.
Eye closure often triggers eyelid myoclonus and absence - repeated eye closure testing is critical.
Eyelid myoclonus (rhythmic jerking of eyelids) is the most characteristic feature - distinguishes from typical absence.
Jeavons has shorter absence duration (3-6 seconds) compared to typical absence (5-30 seconds).
differential_diagnosis: Childhood Absence Epilepsy (CAE) - no eyelid myoclonus, not photosensitive
Juvenile Absence Epilepsy (JAE) - no eyelid myoclonus, less photosensitive
Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME) - myoclonus of limbs, not just eyelids
Atypical Absence (LGS) - gradual onset/offset, slower frequency, cognitive impairment

name: Atypical Absence Seizures

morphology.interictal: Slow spike-and-wave (1.5-2.5 Hz), GPFA, abnormal background
morphology.ictal: Slow spike-and-wave (1.5-2.5 Hz), gradual onset/offset, may be asymmetric
morphology.subtype: Atypical absence - gradual onset/offset, slower frequency
morphology.special_features: Gradual onset and offset (unlike abrupt typical absence), slower frequency, abnormal background

sleep.notes: MOST EFFECTIVE. Slow spike-and-wave and GPFA are most prominent during sleep. Essential to record sleep.

awake.notes: Slow spike-and-wave present but may be less frequent

hyperventilation.notes: Less effective than in typical absence

photic_stimulation.notes: Less effective than in typical absence

recording_duration.notes: Sleep is essential - patterns are most prominent during sleep

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Sleep recording is CRITICAL - slow spike-and-wave and GPFA are most prominent during sleep. Atypical absence is part of LGS syndrome.

manifestation: Gradual onset and offset (unlike abrupt typical absence)
Longer duration (10-60+ seconds, longer than typical absence)
May have atonic components (head drop, loss of tone)
Often occurs in context of LGS

clinical_course.onset: Childhood (1-8 years, typically in LGS context)
clinical_course.outcome: Poor - resistant to treatment, persistent seizures
clinical_course.treatment: Valproate, lamotrigine, rufinamide, felbamate, ketogenic diet, VNS (same as LGS)
clinical_course.prognosis: Poor - part of LGS syndrome, persistent seizures, cognitive impairment

abret_pearls: Atypical absence has gradual onset/offset (unlike abrupt typical absence) - key distinguishing feature.
Atypical absence has slower frequency (1.5-2.5 Hz) compared to typical absence (3 Hz).
Atypical absence occurs in context of LGS with cognitive impairment - distinguishing it from typical absence.
Sleep recording is CRITICAL - slow spike-and-wave is most prominent during sleep.
differential_diagnosis: Typical Absence (CAE/JAE) - abrupt onset/offset, 3 Hz, normal cognition
Absence with Eyelid Myoclonus (Jeavons) - has eyelid myoclonus, photosensitive, normal cognition
Complex partial seizures - focal onset, different semiology

name: Idiopathic Generalized Epilepsy (IGE)

morphology.interictal: Normal background, generalized spike-and-wave patterns (3 Hz, polyspike-and-wave, or slow spike-and-wave)
morphology.ictal: Generalized spike-and-wave patterns, symmetric, synchronous
morphology.frequency: Variable: 3-4 Hz (typical absence), 4-6 Hz (JME), 1.5-2.5 Hz (atypical absence/LGS)
morphology.subtype: Umbrella term for multiple IGE syndromes
morphology.special_features: Includes CAE, JAE, JME, Jeavons, GTCA. Patterns vary by specific syndrome.

hyperventilation.notes: Most effective for CAE (90-95%), less effective for JME (20-30%)

photic_stimulation.notes: Very effective for Jeavons (90-95%), less effective for CAE (10-15%)

sleep_deprivation.notes: Most effective for JME (90-95% with awakening), moderate for CAE (40-50%)

sleep.notes: Essential for LGS/atypical absence (95-100%), less critical for CAE (30-40%)

recording_duration.notes: Longer recordings increase yield. Include activation procedures specific to suspected syndrome.

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: IGE is an umbrella term. Activation procedures vary by specific syndrome (CAE, JAE, JME, Jeavons). Choose activation based on clinical suspicion.

manifestation: Multiple seizure types possible (absence, myoclonic, GTC)
Specific manifestations vary by syndrome (CAE, JAE, JME, Jeavons)

clinical_course.onset: Childhood to young adulthood (varies by specific syndrome)
clinical_course.outcome: Variable - excellent for CAE, good for JAE/JME/Jeavons, poor for LGS
clinical_course.treatment: Valproate, lamotrigine, ethosuximide, levetiracetam (varies by syndrome)
clinical_course.prognosis: Variable - excellent for typical absence (CAE/JAE), good for JME/Jeavons with treatment, poor for LGS

abret_pearls: IGE is an umbrella term including CAE, JAE, JME, Jeavons, and GTCA - each has specific activation procedures.
Hyperventilation is most effective for CAE (90-95% yield) but less effective for JME (20-30% yield).
Photic stimulation is most effective for Jeavons (90-95% yield) but less effective for CAE (10-15% yield).
Sleep deprivation + awakening is most effective for JME (90-95% yield).
All IGE syndromes show generalized, symmetric, synchronous patterns - distinguishing them from focal epilepsies.
Normal background and normal exam/imaging are characteristic of IGE - distinguishing from symptomatic generalized epilepsies.
differential_diagnosis: Symptomatic generalized epilepsies - abnormal exam/imaging, abnormal background
Focal epilepsies - asymmetric onset, focal patterns
Progressive myoclonus epilepsies - progressive course, abnormal exam
Non-epileptic events - normal EEG

name: Ohtahara Syndrome (Early Infantile Epileptic Encephalopathy - EIEE)
age_range: First few days to 3 months (peak: first 2 weeks)

morphology.interictal: Burst-suppression pattern - alternating bursts of high-amplitude activity and suppression
morphology.ictal: Burst-suppression pattern, tonic seizures show bursts or electrodecremental pattern
morphology.frequency: Variable - bursts contain mixed frequencies (delta, theta, spikes)
morphology.amplitude: Very high amplitude bursts (200-1000+ µV), suppression periods near isoelectric
morphology.special_features: Burst-suppression pattern is continuous (present in both wake and sleep), distinguishing it from normal neonatal trace alternant (sleep only)

awake.notes: Burst-suppression pattern is continuous and present in both wake and sleep - CRITICAL for diagnosis

sleep.notes: Burst-suppression pattern persists in sleep (unlike normal trace alternant which is sleep-only)

ictal_recording.notes: Tonic seizures correlate with bursts or electrodecremental pattern. Must correlate with clinical events.

recording_duration.recommended: Minimum 1-2 hours, include both wake and sleep
recording_duration.notes: Must record both wake and sleep to confirm burst-suppression is continuous (not just sleep)

montage.notes: Better shows generalized distribution and suppression periods

video_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG bursts with clinical tonic seizures

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Burst-suppression pattern is CONTINUOUS (wake and sleep) - distinguishing it from normal neonatal trace alternant (sleep only). This is CRITICAL for diagnosis.

clinical_features.seizure_type: Tonic seizures (most characteristic), may have focal seizures
manifestation: Onset in first few days to 3 months (peak: first 2 weeks)
May evolve to West Syndrome (hypsarrhythmia) or LGS
clinical_features.neurological_exam: Severely abnormal (hypotonia, poor feeding, developmental arrest)
clinical_features.imaging: May show structural abnormalities (cortical malformations, hemimegalencephaly, etc.)

clinical_course.onset: Neonatal period (first few days to 3 months, peak: first 2 weeks)
clinical_course.progression: May evolve to West Syndrome (hypsarrhythmia) around 3-6 months, or to LGS
clinical_course.outcome: Very poor - severe developmental delay, high mortality, resistant to treatment
clinical_course.treatment: ACTH, vigabatrin, ketogenic diet, antiepileptic drugs. Often resistant to treatment.
clinical_course.prognosis: Very poor - severe developmental delay, high mortality, persistent seizures

abret_pearls: Ohtahara syndrome shows burst-suppression pattern that is CONTINUOUS (present in both wake and sleep) - distinguishing it from normal neonatal trace alternant (sleep only).
Burst-suppression pattern in Ohtahara is continuous and pathologic - not just during sleep like normal trace alternant.
Onset in first few days to 3 months (peak: first 2 weeks) - earliest onset of epileptic encephalopathies.
Tonic seizures are most characteristic - brief, frequent, correlate with bursts or electrodecremental pattern.
May evolve to West Syndrome (hypsarrhythmia) around 3-6 months, or to LGS - part of epileptic encephalopathy spectrum.
differential_diagnosis: Normal neonatal trace alternant - sleep only, not continuous, normal development
Early Myoclonic Encephalopathy (EME) - has myoclonic seizures, burst-suppression pattern
West Syndrome - later onset (3-12 months), hypsarrhythmia pattern
Severe HIE - history of hypoxic-ischemic injury, burst-suppression pattern

name: Early Myoclonic Encephalopathy (EME)
age_range: First few days to 3 months (peak: first week)

morphology.interictal: Burst-suppression pattern - alternating bursts of high-amplitude activity and suppression
morphology.ictal: Burst-suppression pattern, myoclonic seizures may show bursts or spikes
morphology.frequency: Variable - bursts contain mixed frequencies (delta, theta, spikes)
morphology.amplitude: Very high amplitude bursts (200-1000+ µV), suppression periods near isoelectric
morphology.distribution: Generalized, may be asymmetric or multifocal
morphology.subtype: Neonatal/infantile epileptic encephalopathy - burst-suppression with myoclonus
morphology.special_features: Burst-suppression pattern with myoclonic seizures. Pattern may be more irregular than Ohtahara. Often associated with metabolic disorders.

awake.notes: Burst-suppression pattern is continuous and present in both wake and sleep - CRITICAL for diagnosis

sleep.notes: Burst-suppression pattern persists in sleep

ictal_recording.notes: Myoclonic seizures correlate with bursts or spikes. Must correlate with clinical myoclonus.

recording_duration.recommended: Minimum 1-2 hours, include both wake and sleep
recording_duration.notes: Must record both wake and sleep to confirm burst-suppression is continuous

montage.notes: Better shows generalized distribution and suppression periods. May need EMG channels to see myoclonus.

video_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG bursts/spikes with clinical myoclonic jerks

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Burst-suppression pattern is CONTINUOUS (wake and sleep). Myoclonic seizures are most characteristic. Often associated with metabolic disorders (non-ketotic hyperglycinemia, etc.).

clinical_features.seizure_type: Myoclonic seizures (most characteristic), may have focal seizures, tonic seizures less common
manifestation: Myoclonic seizures (most characteristic) - fragmentary, erratic, multifocal
Onset in first few days to 3 months (peak: first week)
Often associated with metabolic disorders (non-ketotic hyperglycinemia, etc.)
clinical_features.neurological_exam: Severely abnormal (hypotonia, poor feeding, developmental arrest)
clinical_features.imaging: May show structural abnormalities, but often normal (metabolic etiology)

clinical_course.onset: Neonatal period (first few days to 3 months, peak: first week)
clinical_course.progression: May persist or evolve to other patterns, rarely evolves to West Syndrome
clinical_course.outcome: Very poor - severe developmental delay, high mortality, resistant to treatment
clinical_course.treatment: Address underlying metabolic disorder if present, antiepileptic drugs, ketogenic diet. Often resistant to treatment.
clinical_course.prognosis: Very poor - severe developmental delay, high mortality, persistent seizures

abret_pearls: EME shows burst-suppression pattern with MYOCLONIC SEIZURES (most characteristic) - distinguishing it from Ohtahara (tonic seizures).
Burst-suppression pattern in EME is continuous (wake and sleep) - distinguishing it from normal neonatal trace alternant (sleep only).
Onset in first few days to 3 months (peak: first week) - earliest onset, often first week of life.
Myoclonic seizures are fragmentary, erratic, and multifocal - characteristic of EME.
Often associated with metabolic disorders (non-ketotic hyperglycinemia) - check metabolic workup.
EME vs Ohtahara: EME has myoclonic seizures; Ohtahara has tonic seizures. Both have burst-suppression pattern.
differential_diagnosis: Ohtahara Syndrome - tonic seizures (not myoclonic), similar burst-suppression pattern
Normal neonatal trace alternant - sleep only, not continuous, normal development
West Syndrome - later onset (3-12 months), hypsarrhythmia pattern, infantile spasms
Metabolic encephalopathies - similar pattern, check metabolic workup

name: ESES/CSWS (Electrical Status Epilepticus in Sleep / Continuous Spike-and-Wave during Slow Sleep)

morphology.interictal: Awake: may show focal or multifocal spikes, normal or mildly abnormal background
morphology.ictal: Sleep: continuous spike-and-wave during slow-wave sleep (≥85% of NREM sleep)
morphology.distribution: Generalized or bilateral, may be asymmetric, maximal in centrotemporal or frontocentral regions
morphology.duration: Continuous during slow-wave sleep (≥85% of NREM sleep)
morphology.subtype: Electrical status epilepticus in sleep - continuous spike-and-wave during NREM sleep
morphology.special_features: Continuous spike-and-wave during slow-wave sleep (≥85% of NREM sleep). Pattern disappears or dramatically decreases in REM sleep and wakefulness. CRITICAL: Must record sleep to diagnose.

sleep.protocol: Natural sleep, especially NREM sleep (slow-wave sleep)
sleep.notes: MOST EFFECTIVE. ESES pattern is ONLY seen during sleep. Pattern appears in NREM sleep and disappears in REM sleep. Essential to record sleep.

awake.notes: May show focal or multifocal spikes, but ESES pattern (continuous spike-and-wave) is NOT present during wakefulness

recording_duration.recommended: Minimum 2-3 hours, must include full sleep cycle (NREM and REM)
recording_duration.notes: Must record full sleep cycle to see ESES in NREM and disappearance in REM. Longer recordings increase yield.

video_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG with clinical seizures and cognitive/behavioral changes

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Sleep recording is CRITICAL - ESES pattern is ONLY seen during NREM sleep (≥85% of slow-wave sleep). Pattern disappears in REM sleep and wakefulness. This is the defining feature.

manifestation: Seizures may be infrequent or absent
Seizures when present: focal, GTC, atypical absence, myoclonic
clinical_features.neurological_exam: May be normal or show cognitive/behavioral deficits

clinical_course.progression: Variable - may remit by adolescence, may persist
clinical_course.outcome: Variable - depends on duration and treatment response
clinical_course.treatment: Benzodiazepines (clobazam, diazepam), valproate, ethosuximide, ketogenic diet, corticosteroids, IVIG. Avoid carbamazepine (may worsen seizures - AED-induced seizure worsening). Treatment aimed at suppressing ESES pattern.
clinical_course.prognosis: Variable - better if treated early, worse if ESES pattern persists long-term

abret_pearls: ESES pattern is ONLY seen during NREM sleep (≥85% of slow-wave sleep) - sleep recording is CRITICAL for diagnosis.
ESES pattern disappears in REM sleep and wakefulness - must record full sleep cycle to see this pattern.
Cognitive regression is the most characteristic clinical feature - may occur even without frequent seizures.
ESES = Continuous spike-and-wave during slow-wave sleep (≥85% of NREM sleep) - this is the defining EEG feature.
Landau-Kleffner Syndrome is a specific form of ESES with acquired aphasia (language loss) as the primary feature.
differential_diagnosis: Landau-Kleffner Syndrome - ESES with acquired aphasia (language loss)
Benign Rolandic Epilepsy - centrotemporal spikes, normal cognition, remits by adolescence
LGS - slow spike-and-wave, multiple seizure types, cognitive impairment, pattern present in wake and sleep
Normal sleep patterns - ESES is pathologic, not normal sleep activity

name: Landau-Kleffner Syndrome (LKS)

morphology.interictal: Awake: may show focal or multifocal spikes (often temporal or perisylvian), normal or mildly abnormal background
morphology.ictal: Sleep: ESES pattern - continuous spike-and-wave during slow-wave sleep (≥85% of NREM sleep)
morphology.distribution: Generalized or bilateral, often maximal in temporal or perisylvian regions
morphology.duration: Continuous during slow-wave sleep (≥85% of NREM sleep)
morphology.subtype: ESES with acquired aphasia - Landau-Kleffner Syndrome
morphology.special_features: ESES pattern (continuous spike-and-wave during NREM sleep) with ACQUIRED APHASIA (language loss). Pattern disappears in REM sleep and wakefulness. CRITICAL: Must record sleep to diagnose.

sleep.protocol: Natural sleep, especially NREM sleep (slow-wave sleep)
sleep.notes: MOST EFFECTIVE. ESES pattern is ONLY seen during sleep. Pattern appears in NREM sleep and disappears in REM sleep. Essential to record sleep.

awake.notes: May show focal or multifocal spikes (often temporal/perisylvian), but ESES pattern is NOT present during wakefulness

recording_duration.recommended: Minimum 2-3 hours, must include full sleep cycle (NREM and REM)
recording_duration.notes: Must record full sleep cycle to see ESES in NREM and disappearance in REM. Longer recordings increase yield.

montage.notes: Better shows generalized/bilateral distribution. Temporal/perisylvian emphasis may be seen.

video_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG with clinical seizures and language regression

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Sleep recording is CRITICAL - ESES pattern is ONLY seen during NREM sleep. Landau-Kleffner is ESES with acquired aphasia (language loss) as the primary feature.

manifestation: Verbal auditory agnosia (inability to understand spoken language)
Seizures may be infrequent or absent (paradoxical - seizures rare but EEG shows ESES)
Seizures when present: focal (often temporal), GTC, atypical absence
clinical_features.neurological_exam: May be normal except for language deficits
clinical_features.development: Acquired language regression (previously normal language development)

clinical_course.progression: Variable - language may improve with treatment, may persist
clinical_course.outcome: Variable - depends on duration of ESES and treatment response. Language recovery may be incomplete.
clinical_course.treatment: Benzodiazepines (clobazam, diazepam), valproate, ethosuximide, ketogenic diet, corticosteroids, IVIG, multiple subpial transection (MST) in severe cases. Avoid carbamazepine (may worsen seizures - AED-induced seizure worsening). Treatment aimed at suppressing ESES pattern.
clinical_course.prognosis: Variable - better if treated early, worse if ESES pattern persists long-term. Language recovery may be incomplete.

abret_pearls: Landau-Kleffner Syndrome = ESES pattern + ACQUIRED APHASIA (language loss) - this is the defining clinical feature.
ESES pattern is ONLY seen during NREM sleep (≥85% of slow-wave sleep) - sleep recording is CRITICAL for diagnosis.
Acquired aphasia (language loss) is the most characteristic clinical feature - distinguishes LKS from other ESES cases.
Paradoxical: Seizures may be infrequent or absent, but EEG shows continuous spike-and-wave during sleep (ESES).
ESES pattern disappears in REM sleep and wakefulness - must record full sleep cycle to see this pattern.
differential_diagnosis: ESES/CSWS without aphasia - similar EEG pattern but no language loss
Autism spectrum disorder - language delay from onset, not acquired loss
Benign Rolandic Epilepsy - centrotemporal spikes, normal cognition, remits by adolescence
LGS - slow spike-and-wave, multiple seizure types, pattern present in wake and sleep

name: Dravet Syndrome (Severe Myoclonic Epilepsy of Infancy - SMEI)
age_range: First year of life (peak 6 months), persists into childhood

morphology.interictal: Early: may be normal. Later: generalized spike-and-wave, polyspike-and-wave, multifocal spikes, photosensitive
morphology.ictal: Generalized spike-and-wave, polyspike-and-wave, focal/multifocal patterns
morphology.distribution: Generalized, may be asymmetric, may be multifocal
morphology.subtype: Severe myoclonic epilepsy of infancy - photosensitive, fever-sensitive
morphology.special_features: Photosensitive (pattern triggered by photic stimulation). Fever-sensitive (seizures triggered by fever). Pattern evolves over time - early may be normal, later shows generalized/multifocal abnormalities.

photic_stimulation.notes: Dravet is photosensitive - photic stimulation may trigger seizures or EEG abnormalities

sleep.notes: May show generalized spike-and-wave, polyspike-and-wave during sleep

awake.notes: May show generalized or multifocal spikes

ictal_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG with clinical seizures (febrile, myoclonic, focal, GTC)

recording_duration.notes: Longer recordings increase yield. Include photic stimulation.

video_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG with multiple seizure types

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Dravet is photosensitive and fever-sensitive. Photic stimulation may trigger seizures. Early EEG may be normal, pattern evolves over time.

manifestation: Febrile seizures in first year (most characteristic early feature)
clinical_features.imaging: Usually normal (may show mild atrophy later)
clinical_features.development: Developmental delay and regression (after initial normal development)

clinical_course.onset: First year of life (peak 6 months) - febrile seizures
clinical_course.progression: Chronic, persistent, may worsen over time
clinical_course.outcome: Poor - resistant to treatment, persistent seizures, developmental delay
clinical_course.treatment: Valproate, clobazam, stiripentol, topiramate, ketogenic diet, fenfluramine, cannabidiol. Avoid lamotrigine and carbamazepine (may worsen seizures - AED-induced seizure worsening).
clinical_course.prognosis: Poor - persistent seizures, developmental delay, cognitive impairment, high mortality risk

abret_pearls: Dravet syndrome begins with febrile seizures in first year of life (peak 6 months) - this is the most characteristic early feature.
Dravet is photosensitive - photic stimulation may trigger seizures or EEG abnormalities (60-80% yield).
Dravet is fever-sensitive - seizures triggered by fever, hot baths, illness. Avoid fever triggers.
Early EEG may be normal - pattern evolves over time to show generalized spike-and-wave, polyspike-and-wave, multifocal spikes.
Status epilepticus is common in Dravet - may be prolonged and difficult to control.
Multiple seizure types develop over time: febrile → myoclonic → focal → GTC → atypical absence.
differential_diagnosis: Simple febrile seizures - no developmental delay, normal EEG, remits
GEFS+ (Genetic Epilepsy with Febrile Seizures Plus) - milder, better prognosis
LGS - later onset, slow spike-and-wave, different pattern
Other myoclonic epilepsies - different age of onset, different triggers

name: Epilepsy with Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizures Alone (GTCA)

morphology.interictal: Normal background, occasional generalized spike-and-wave or polyspike-and-wave
morphology.ictal: Generalized spike-and-wave or polyspike-and-wave, may show fast activity during GTC
morphology.subtype: Generalized tonic-clonic seizures only - no absence, no myoclonus
morphology.special_features: Seizures often occur upon awakening or during sleep. No absence seizures, no myoclonic seizures - only GTC.

sleep_deprivation.protocol: 4-6 hours sleep deprivation, record upon awakening
sleep_deprivation.notes: GTC seizures often occur upon awakening - critical activation procedure

sleep.notes: GTC seizures often occur during sleep or upon awakening

awake.notes: May show interictal spikes but seizures less common during wakefulness

recording_duration.recommended: Include sleep and awakening, minimum 30 minutes
recording_duration.notes: Record upon awakening - critical for GTCA

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: GTC seizures often occur upon awakening or during sleep. Sleep deprivation with recording upon awakening is most effective.

clinical_course.outcome: Good with treatment
clinical_course.treatment: Valproate, lamotrigine, levetiracetam, topiramate
clinical_course.prognosis: Good with treatment, may remit or require lifelong medication

abret_pearls: GTCA = Generalized tonic-clonic seizures ONLY - no absence, no myoclonus. This distinguishes it from JME (has myoclonus) and CAE (has absence).
GTC seizures often occur upon awakening - sleep deprivation with recording upon awakening is most effective (70-80% yield).
Normal background and normal exam/imaging are characteristic - distinguishing from symptomatic generalized epilepsies.
differential_diagnosis: JME - has myoclonic seizures, GTC upon awakening
CAE/JAE - has absence seizures, not just GTC
Symptomatic generalized epilepsies - abnormal exam/imaging, abnormal background

name: Benign Myoclonic Epilepsy of Infancy (BMEI)

morphology.interictal: Normal background, occasional generalized spike-and-wave or polyspike-and-wave
morphology.ictal: Generalized spike-and-wave or polyspike-and-wave during myoclonic jerks
morphology.subtype: Benign myoclonic epilepsy of infancy - myoclonic seizures only
morphology.special_features: Myoclonic seizures only (no GTC, no absence). Normal development. Good prognosis. Distinguishes from Dravet (severe, developmental delay).

sleep.notes: May show spikes during sleep but myoclonus less common

recording_duration.notes: Myoclonic jerks occur during wakefulness

montage.notes: Better shows generalized distribution. May need EMG channels to see myoclonus.

video_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG spikes with clinical myoclonic jerks

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Myoclonic seizures only (no GTC, no absence). Normal development. Good prognosis. Distinguishes from Dravet (severe, developmental delay, multiple seizure types).

triggers: May be triggered by photic stimulation (in photosensitive)

clinical_course.onset: Infancy (6 months to 3 years, peak 1-2 years)
clinical_course.outcome: Excellent - remits by age 3-5 years, normal development
clinical_course.treatment: Valproate, levetiracetam. May not require treatment if infrequent.
clinical_course.prognosis: Excellent - complete remission, normal development, no cognitive impairment

abret_pearls: BMEI = Myoclonic seizures ONLY (no GTC, no absence) - this distinguishes it from Dravet (multiple seizure types, developmental delay).
Normal development is characteristic - distinguishing it from Dravet (developmental delay) and other severe myoclonic epilepsies.
Excellent prognosis - remits by age 3-5 years, normal development. This is a benign condition.
BMEI vs Dravet: BMEI has normal development and good prognosis; Dravet has developmental delay and poor prognosis.
differential_diagnosis: Dravet Syndrome - multiple seizure types, developmental delay, poor prognosis, fever-sensitive
JME - later onset (adolescence), GTC seizures, persists into adulthood
Progressive myoclonus epilepsies - progressive course, abnormal exam

name: Doose Syndrome (Myoclonic-Astatic Epilepsy - MAE)

morphology.interictal: Normal or mildly abnormal background, generalized spike-and-wave or polyspike-and-wave
morphology.ictal: Generalized spike-and-wave or polyspike-and-wave during myoclonic-astatic seizures
morphology.subtype: Myoclonic-astatic epilepsy - myoclonic followed by atonic (drop attacks)
morphology.special_features: Myoclonic-astatic seizures (myoclonic jerk followed by atonic drop). May have absence seizures. Variable prognosis - may remit or evolve to LGS.

sleep.notes: May show spikes during sleep

recording_duration.notes: Longer recordings increase yield

video_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG with myoclonic-astatic seizures (myoclonic jerk followed by atonic drop)

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Myoclonic-astatic seizures (myoclonic jerk followed by atonic drop) are characteristic. Variable prognosis - may remit or evolve to LGS.

manifestation: Myoclonic-astatic seizures (most characteristic) - myoclonic jerk followed by atonic drop (drop attacks)
Variable course - may remit or evolve to LGS
clinical_features.development: Normal initially, may develop delay if evolves to LGS

clinical_course.progression: Variable - may remit by age 5-10 years, may evolve to LGS
clinical_course.outcome: Variable - good if remits, poor if evolves to LGS
clinical_course.treatment: Valproate, lamotrigine, ethosuximide, ketogenic diet. Avoid carbamazepine (may worsen).
clinical_course.prognosis: Variable - good if remits, poor if evolves to LGS with cognitive impairment

abret_pearls: Doose Syndrome (MAE) = Myoclonic-astatic seizures (myoclonic jerk followed by atonic drop) - this is the most characteristic feature.
Myoclonic-astatic seizures are characteristic - myoclonic jerk immediately followed by atonic drop (drop attacks).
Variable prognosis - may remit by age 5-10 years (good), or may evolve to LGS (poor).
Avoid carbamazepine in Doose Syndrome - may worsen seizures (AED-induced seizure worsening).
Doose vs LGS: Doose may remit; LGS is chronic. Both have multiple seizure types and drop attacks.
differential_diagnosis: LGS - chronic, persistent, slow spike-and-wave, cognitive impairment
BMEI - myoclonic only, normal development, remits by age 3-5 years
Dravet Syndrome - earlier onset, febrile seizures, developmental delay, photosensitive

name: Eye Closure Sensitivity Epilepsy

morphology.interictal: Normal background, occasional generalized spike-and-wave or polyspike-and-wave
morphology.ictal: Generalized spike-and-wave or polyspike-and-wave, triggered by eye closure
morphology.subtype: Eye closure sensitive - seizures triggered by eye closure
morphology.special_features: Seizures triggered by eye closure. May be associated with Jeavons (eyelid myoclonus) or may be broader eye closure sensitivity. Pattern appears immediately after eye closure.

eye_closure.notes: MOST EFFECTIVE. Eye closure triggers seizures or EEG abnormalities. Critical activation procedure.

photic_stimulation.protocol: Standard IPS protocol, especially with eye closure
photic_stimulation.notes: Eye closure during photic stimulation may enhance response

awake.protocol: Awake recording with eye closure testing
awake.notes: Must include repeated eye closure testing

recording_duration.recommended: Minimum 20-30 minutes awake, include eye closure testing
recording_duration.notes: Must include repeated eye closure testing - critical for diagnosis

montage.notes: Better shows generalized distribution. May need EOG channels to see eye closure.

video_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG changes with eye closure and clinical events

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Eye closure is CRITICAL activation procedure (85-95% yield). Repeated eye closure testing is essential. May be associated with Jeavons (eyelid myoclonus) or may be broader eye closure sensitivity.

manifestation: Seizures triggered by eye closure (most characteristic)

clinical_course.onset: Childhood to adolescence (2-14 years, peak 6-10 years)
clinical_course.outcome: Variable - good with treatment, may persist
clinical_course.treatment: Valproate, lamotrigine, levetiracetam. Avoidance of eye closure triggers.
clinical_course.prognosis: Good with treatment, but eye closure sensitivity may persist

abret_pearls: Eye closure is the most effective activation procedure for eye closure sensitivity epilepsy (85-95% yield) - repeated eye closure testing is CRITICAL.
Seizures triggered by eye closure - pattern appears immediately after eye closure.
May be associated with Jeavons (eyelid myoclonus) or may be broader eye closure sensitivity.
Eye closure during photic stimulation may enhance response - test both together.
differential_diagnosis: Jeavons Syndrome - has eyelid myoclonus, highly photosensitive, eye closure triggers
CAE/JAE - absence seizures, not triggered by eye closure
Other photosensitive epilepsies - triggered by photic, not eye closure

name: Angelman Syndrome (with Epilepsy)

morphology.interictal: Abnormal background, generalized spike-and-wave or slow spike-and-wave, may be photosensitive
morphology.ictal: Generalized spike-and-wave, slow spike-and-wave, may show fast activity
morphology.frequency: Variable - 2-4 Hz spike-and-wave or slow spike-and-wave (1.5-2.5 Hz)
morphology.subtype: Genetic syndrome with epilepsy - Angelman Syndrome
morphology.special_features: Genetic condition (15q11-13 deletion/mutation). Characteristic clinical features (happy demeanor, ataxia, developmental delay). EEG shows generalized spike-and-wave or slow spike-and-wave. May be photosensitive.

sleep.notes: May show slow spike-and-wave during sleep

photic_stimulation.notes: May be photosensitive - photic stimulation may trigger seizures

recording_duration.notes: Longer recordings increase yield

video_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG with clinical seizures and characteristic clinical features

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Genetic condition with characteristic clinical features (happy demeanor, ataxia, developmental delay). EEG shows generalized patterns. May be photosensitive.

manifestation: Characteristic clinical features: happy demeanor, frequent laughter, ataxia, developmental delay

clinical_course.outcome: Poor - persistent seizures, severe developmental delay
clinical_course.treatment: Valproate, clobazam, levetiracetam, ketogenic diet. Avoid carbamazepine (may worsen).
clinical_course.prognosis: Poor - persistent seizures, severe developmental delay, lifelong condition

abret_pearls: Angelman Syndrome is a genetic condition (15q11-13 deletion/mutation) with characteristic clinical features: happy demeanor, frequent laughter, ataxia, developmental delay.
EEG shows generalized spike-and-wave or slow spike-and-wave - may be photosensitive.
Avoid carbamazepine in Angelman Syndrome - may worsen seizures (AED-induced seizure worsening).
Characteristic clinical features (happy demeanor, ataxia) help distinguish from other epileptic encephalopathies.
differential_diagnosis: LGS - similar EEG pattern but different clinical features (no happy demeanor)
Other genetic epileptic encephalopathies - different genetic causes, different clinical features
Rett Syndrome - different clinical features (hand wringing, regression)

name: Rett Syndrome (with Epilepsy)
age_range: Infancy to childhood (seizures onset 2-5 years, after regression)

morphology.interictal: Abnormal background, generalized spike-and-wave or slow spike-and-wave, may show focal spikes
morphology.ictal: Generalized spike-and-wave, slow spike-and-wave, may show focal patterns
morphology.frequency: Variable - 2-4 Hz spike-and-wave or slow spike-and-wave (1.5-2.5 Hz)
morphology.distribution: Generalized, may be asymmetric, may be multifocal
morphology.subtype: Genetic syndrome with epilepsy - Rett Syndrome
morphology.special_features: Genetic condition (MECP2 mutation). Characteristic clinical features (hand wringing, developmental regression, loss of purposeful hand use). EEG shows generalized or multifocal patterns. Pattern may worsen over time.

sleep.notes: May show slow spike-and-wave or multifocal spikes during sleep

awake.notes: May show generalized or multifocal spikes

recording_duration.notes: Longer recordings increase yield

video_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG with clinical seizures and characteristic clinical features (hand wringing, etc.)

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Genetic condition (MECP2 mutation) with characteristic clinical features (hand wringing, developmental regression). EEG shows generalized or multifocal patterns. Pattern may worsen over time.

manifestation: Characteristic clinical features: hand wringing, loss of purposeful hand use, developmental regression
clinical_features.neurological_exam: Abnormal (ataxia, developmental delay, characteristic hand wringing)
clinical_features.development: Severe developmental delay and regression (after initial normal development)

clinical_course.onset: Infancy to childhood (seizures onset 2-5 years, after regression)
clinical_course.progression: Chronic, persistent, may worsen over time
clinical_course.outcome: Poor - persistent seizures, severe developmental delay and regression
clinical_course.treatment: Valproate, clobazam, levetiracetam, ketogenic diet. Avoid carbamazepine (may worsen).
clinical_course.prognosis: Poor - persistent seizures, severe developmental delay and regression, lifelong condition

abret_pearls: Rett Syndrome is a genetic condition (MECP2 mutation) with characteristic clinical features: hand wringing, loss of purposeful hand use, developmental regression.
EEG shows generalized spike-and-wave or slow spike-and-wave - may be multifocal. Pattern may worsen over time.
Avoid carbamazepine in Rett Syndrome - may worsen seizures (AED-induced seizure worsening).
Characteristic clinical features (hand wringing, developmental regression) help distinguish from other epileptic encephalopathies.
Developmental regression after initial normal development is characteristic - distinguishes from conditions with delay from onset.
differential_diagnosis: LGS - similar EEG pattern but different clinical features (no hand wringing)
Angelman Syndrome - different clinical features (happy demeanor, no hand wringing)
Other genetic epileptic encephalopathies - different genetic causes, different clinical features

name: Lissencephaly and Subcortical Band Heterotopia (with Epilepsy)
age_range: Infancy to childhood (seizures onset variable, often early)

morphology.interictal: Abnormal background, generalized spike-and-wave or slow spike-and-wave, may show hypsarrhythmia
morphology.ictal: Generalized spike-and-wave, slow spike-and-wave, may show fast activity or electrodecremental pattern
morphology.frequency: Variable - 1.5-4 Hz spike-and-wave or slow spike-and-wave
morphology.distribution: Generalized, may be asymmetric, may be multifocal
morphology.subtype: Structural brain malformation with epilepsy - lissencephaly/band heterotopia
morphology.special_features: Structural brain malformation (smooth brain - lissencephaly, or subcortical band heterotopia). EEG shows generalized patterns. May show hypsarrhythmia in infancy. Pattern correlates with severity of malformation.

sleep.notes: May show slow spike-and-wave or hypsarrhythmia during sleep

awake.notes: May show generalized spike-and-wave or slow spike-and-wave

ictal_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG with clinical seizures and structural imaging findings

recording_duration.notes: Longer recordings increase yield

video_recording.notes: Must correlate EEG with clinical seizures and structural imaging findings

diagnostic_yield_enhancement.special_notes: Structural brain malformation (lissencephaly = smooth brain, or subcortical band heterotopia). EEG shows generalized patterns. May show hypsarrhythmia in infancy. Pattern correlates with severity of malformation.

manifestation: Structural brain malformation (lissencephaly = smooth brain, or subcortical band heterotopia)
clinical_features.imaging: Abnormal - shows lissencephaly (smooth brain) or subcortical band heterotopia

clinical_course.onset: Infancy to childhood (seizures onset variable, often early)
clinical_course.outcome: Very poor - persistent seizures, severe developmental delay
clinical_course.treatment: ACTH, vigabatrin, valproate, ketogenic diet. Treatment of underlying structural malformation not possible. Seizure management only.
clinical_course.prognosis: Very poor - persistent seizures, severe developmental delay, high mortality, lifelong condition

abret_pearls: Lissencephaly = smooth brain (lack of gyri and sulci). Subcortical band heterotopia = band of gray matter in white matter. Both are structural malformations with epilepsy.
EEG shows generalized spike-and-wave or slow spike-and-wave - may show hypsarrhythmia in infancy.
Structural imaging (MRI) is essential for diagnosis - shows lissencephaly or subcortical band heterotopia.
Pattern correlates with severity of malformation - more severe malformation = more severe EEG abnormalities.
May show infantile spasms early - may evolve to other seizure types over time.
differential_diagnosis: West Syndrome - hypsarrhythmia, infantile spasms, but no structural malformation on imaging
LGS - slow spike-and-wave, multiple seizure types, but no structural malformation on imaging
Other structural malformations - different imaging findings
